Report of Legislative Debate on the State Bank of Illinois, 11 January 1837 REMARKS OF MR.LINCOLN, In theHouse of Representatives, upon the resolution offered by Mr.Linder, to institute an enquiry into the management of the affairs of theState Bank.1 (Here Mr. Linder called to order. The Chair decided that Mr. Lincoln was not out

of order. Mr. Linder appealed to the House;—but before the question was put, withdrew

his appeal, saying, he preferred to let the gentleman go on; he thought he would break

his own neck. Mr. Lincoln proceeded)—

footnotes.text:
1On January 7, 1837, Usher F. Linder  proposed for adoption a resolution calling for
                  the appointment of a select committee of seven persons to investigate the State Bank
                  of Illinois.  The House tabled the resolution and ordered 150 copies printed by a
                  vote of 61 yeas to 14 nays, with Abraham Lincoln voting yea. On January 11, the House
                  agreed to allow Linder to move to take up the resolution by a vote of  55 yeas to
                  21 nays, with Lincoln voting nay.  The House then agreed to take up the resolution
                  by a vote of 57 yeas to 24 nays, with Lincoln voting nay.  Lincoln’s remarks came
                  in the midst of the ensuing debate.Illinois HouseJournal. 1836. 10th G. A., 1st sess., 195-99, 235-36.

2The original source text for this paragraph is damaged (a section of the column is
                  torn away).  The text within the supplied elements comes from the transcription in
                  Roy P. Basler,The Collected Works of Abraham Lincoln(New Brunswick, NJ: Rutgers University Press, 1953), 1:63.

3The original source text for this paragraph is damaged (a section of the column is
                  torn away).  The text within the supplied elements comes  from the transcription in
                  Roy P. Basler,The Collected Works of Abraham Lincoln, 1:64-65.

4The original source text for this paragraph is damaged (a section of the column is
                  torn away).  The text within the supplied elements comes from the transcription in
                  Roy P. Basler, Basler,The Collected Works of Abraham Lincoln, 1:65.
5“An Act to Regulate the Interest of Money,” 28 February 1833,Revised Laws of Illinois(1833), 348-50.
6This may beEdward M. Wilsonof Vermilion County, Illinois.

7In 1831, the General Assembly had authorized borrowing $100,000 from Samuel Wiggins
                  to replenish the school fund, from which the legislature had borrowed to pay state
                  expenses, and to redeem State Bank of Illinois bank notes, which the state had purchased
                  at a heavy discount and which became due in 1831 at face value in specie.After debate on the resolution, the House referred it to the Committee of the Whole.
                  On January 18, the House discharged the Committee of the Whole from further consideration.
                  Linder proposed to amend the resolution by striking out all after the word “Resolved”
                  and inserting a substitute calling for a select committee of five to investigate the
                  bank.John J. Hardincountered with his own substitute calling for the House and Senate finance committees
                  to conduct the inquiry.  Hardin later modified his substitute making it a joint select
                  committee of three members of the House and two from the Senate. The House rejected
                  Hardin’ substitute as modified by a vote of 39 yeas to 45 nays, with Lincoln voting
                  yea.  The House refused to refer the resolution and Linder’s proposed substitute to
                  a select committee by a vote of 23 yeas to 60 nays, with Lincoln voting nay.  The
                  House rejected Lincoln’s motion to amend the proposed substitute by striking out the
                  word “organization” by a vote of 34 yeas to 44 nays, with Lincoln voting yea.  After
                  several procedural votes, the House agreed to strike out the original resolution by
                  a vote of 76 yeas to 10 nays, with Lincoln voting yea.  The House agreed to insert
                  Linder’s substitute by a vote of 66 yeas to 21 nays, with Lincoln voting nay. On January
                  19, the Senate adopted two resolutions, one that mirrored Hardin’s substitute as modified
                  calling for a joint select committee to inquire into  the condition and financial
                  dealings of the State Bank, and the second calling for a joint select committee to
                  inquire into the affairs of the Bank of Illinois.  The House amended the resolution
                  on the State Bank  and adopted the resolution as amended by a vote of 70 yeas to 10
                  nays, with Lincoln voting nay.  The House also adopted the second resolution by a
                  vote of 44 yeas to 35 yeas, with Lincoln voting nay.  On January 20, the Senate concurred
                  in the House amendments.  On February 18, the joint select committee appointed to
                  investigate the State Bank issued its report.Reg Ankrom,Stephen A. Douglas: The Political Apprenticeship, 1833-1843(Jefferson, NC: McFarland, 2015), 79-80; 
                     Illinois HouseJournal. 1836. 10th G. A., 1st sess., 236-37, 247, 288-94, 295-97,  299-300, 303-6, 316,
                     616-23; Illinois SenateJournal. 1836. 10th G. A., 1st sess., 244-45, 252-54, 261.
